author: By Amy Qin
title: F.B.I. Agents Board Ship Managed by Company of Vessel in Baltimore Bridge Collapse
description: The move comes three days after the Justice Department’s civil lawsuit against the owner and operator of the Dali, which struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March.
content: F.B.I. agents on Saturday boarded a container ship that is managed by the same parent company as the cargo vessel that collided with the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore in March, which had toppled the structure and killed six workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Albania Is Planning a New Muslim State Inside Its Capital
description: Prime Minister Edi Rama says he wants to give members of the Bektashi, a Shiite Sufi order, their own Vatican-style enclave as a way of promoting religious tolerance.
content: The Muslim cleric preparing to lead what, if everything goes as planned, will become the world’s smallest state, has laid-back plans for the tiny new country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Who Was Ahmed Wahbi, a Hezbollah Commander Killed in Israel’s Airstrike in Beirut?
description: The senior Hezbollah leader trained the group’s elite fighting unit and led its support for Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks, the Lebanese militia said.
content: Hezbollah said Saturday that Ahmed Wahbi, a commander it described as a leader and trainer in the group’s elite Radwan force, had been killed in an airstrike along with the force’s founding commander, Ibrahim Aqeel, and other Hezbollah members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Attacks on Hezbollah Alter Balance of Power in Long-Running Fight
description: A focus on mutual deterrence had kept intermittent clashes along the Lebanon-Israel border from spiraling into a major war. That changed this past week.
content: For the second time in less than two months, Israel located and killed Hezbollah’s most senior and secretive military figures as they held covert meetings near Beirut. And in between those strikes, Israel incapacitated hundreds, if not thousands, of the group’s rank-and-file members by remotely blowing up their pagers and walkie-talkies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: For Americans Haunted by Beirut Bombings, a Killing Resurfaces Decades of Pain
description: The death of a Hezbollah leader wanted for his role in the 1983 attacks drew a range of reactions from survivors and victims’ families but brought little resolution.
content: Two deadly bombings in Beirut, Lebanon, that killed scores of U.S. military personnel more than 40 years ago have cast a long shadow over survivors and victims’ families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Arizona Court Allows 98,000 to Vote in State and Local Races Despite Database Glitch
description: Officials recently discovered that some people with driver’s licenses issued before 1996 might not have proof of citizenship on file, a state requirement since 2004.
content: Arizona’s Supreme Court ruled on Friday that nearly 100,000 residents whom officials could not verify were U.S. citizens because of an administrative glitch would remain eligible to vote in state and local elections in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Her Children Were Sick. Was It ‘Forever Chemicals’ on the Family Farm?
description: Pastures were fertilized with toxic sewage decades ago. Nobody knew, until the cows’ milk was tested.
content: Allison Jumper’s family was a picture of healthy living. Active kids. Wholesome meals. A freezer stocked with organic beef from her in-laws’ farm in Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Liz Cheney Suggests a New Political Party May Be Needed
description: Ms. Cheney, a longtime Republican, said that the G.O.P. “has rejected the Constitution in the name of supporting Trump” and that Mike Johnson should not be speaker.
content: Former Representative Liz Cheney, who has emerged as perhaps the most vocal and visible conservative critic of former President Donald J. Trump, suggested on Friday night that a new political party might need to be created to replace the Republican Party if he is defeated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Leader of Kenya, Donor to Haiti Police Force, Makes First Visit
description: The trip by President William Ruto of Kenya came against a bleak backdrop in Haiti, where gangs operate with impunity and the Kenyan officers remain largely out of sight.
content: The president of Kenya visited Port-au-Prince on Saturday for his first tour of the base where an understaffed and ill-equipped contingent of nearly 400 of his country’s police officers are trying to bring peace to Haiti, nearly seven months after a gang uprising took thousands of lives and toppled the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Works on a Loop, Say
description: David Karp’s puzzle sends us up, down and all around.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is David Karp’s fifth crossword for The New York Times in just about two years. All of his grids have run on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday, so he’s building out a portfolio of tough stuff. I did great for most of my solve, chuckling away at the fun phrase entries and enjoying the geography trivia that sent me down several interesting rabbit holes. However, I got snagged right at the finish line by some thorny misdirection. I was one letter away from finishing for the longest time! We’ve all been there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: U.S. Soldier Pleads Guilty to Desertion After Fleeing Into North Korea
description: Pvt. Travis King on Friday pleaded guilty before a military judge to desertion, among other charges, after he made an unauthorized crossing into North Korea in 2023.
content: A U.S. Army soldier who had been detained in North Korea after he fled there in 2023 pleaded guilty to desertion, disobeying an order and assault at a hearing on Friday, according to the Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Snyder
title: Freedom Is Not What We Think It Is
description: Freedom is not just an absence of evil. Freedom is the presence of good.
content: I know a town in southern Ukraine where every single house has been destroyed by shelling or bombing. Even the ruins are riddled by bullet holes. Posad-Pokrovske, in the Kherson region, was occupied by Russians for most of 2022, before they were driven out by the Ukrainian army.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Couples Withstand Wrenching Plights Brought On By War
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 21, 2024
content: “I was a stranger there and I am a stranger here. I’m a stranger everywhere.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk, Nicholas Nehamas, Maggie Haberman and Michael Gold
title: Harris Agrees to a Second Debate, but Trump Declines
description: Vice President Kamala Harris, who was widely seen as the winner of the Sept. 10 debate against former President Donald J. Trump, has accepted a debate invitation from CNN.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Saturday that she had accepted an invitation from CNN to participate in a second presidential debate next month, putting pressure on former President Donald J. Trump to join her for a rematch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The 2024 Election Is a Retreat From Ideology
description: Whatever the Trump-Harris election season is delivering, it isn’t a grand ideological debate.
content: The election of 2016, both Donald Trump’s shocking victory and Bernie Sanders’s socialist insurgency, created a sudden swell of ideological ambition. Conservative thinkers rushed to fill in the outlines of Trumpian populism, building various intellectual frameworks for an incipient “post-liberal” age. Meanwhile among progressives there were two big projects: a cultural revolution in the name of antiracism and social justice that gathered force throughout Trump’s presidency, and a Sanders-inspired revival of big-spending social democratic blueprints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Trump’s Opponents See New Ways to Cast the G.O.P. as ‘Team Misogyny’
description: The issue of gender dominated the campaign over a week that included a scandal in North Carolina and reporting on the fatal fallout of abortion bans.
content: In a race between a Democrat who could be America’s first female president and a Republican who has been found liable for sexual abuse, the issue of gender was always going to be inescapable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Car Parts, Fiberglass and a Dream: How a Teacher Built a Hovercraft
description: Robert Tymofichuk, a teacher in Alberta, Canada, spent nearly 2,000 hours building an operational hovercraft from salvaged car parts and with no blueprint.
content: On a cold spring day in a small garage in Alberta, Canada, an engine revved up and an improbable machine — fabricated from auto parts, a hand-sewn rubber skirt and an abandoned fiberglass hull — came to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canadian Doctors Group Apologizes for Health Harms to Indigenous People
description: Indigenous patients faced abuse, experimental treatments and other harms in Canada’s health system, which still has disparities.
content: The medical researchers poked and prodded their unwitting patients. Using sharp instruments, they removed skin from some and grafted the bits onto others in the group of Inuit patients in Igloolik, a hamlet in the Canadian high Arctic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Parnell and Ed Shanahan
title: N.Y.P.D. Understated Woman’s Wound in Subway Shooting, Lawyer Says
description: Kerry Gahalal, who was struck when officers shot a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn station, was not simply “grazed” as officials said, according to a lawyer for the woman’s family.
content: A 26-year-old woman who was wounded when New York City police officers shot a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn subway station was not “grazed” by gunfire as officials have said, according to a lawyer for her family. Instead, the lawyer said on Saturday, she has a bullet lodged in her leg and is unable to walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Read Excerpts From Memos Written for Trump About His Powers to Prosecute
description: The drafts were written to explain the limits of a president’s ability to go after rivals, invoking legal and constitutional factors and political norms.
content: The following are excerpts from draft memos written by lawyers in the White House Counsel’s Office in the spring of 2018 in response to demands from President Donald J. Trump for investigations into rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Hosts a Final ‘Quad Summit’ at His Delaware Home
description: The president has often said that “all politics is personal.” On Saturday, he opened his home in Wilmington to the leaders of Australia, India and Japan.
content: President Biden hosted the leaders of Australia, India and Japan at his home in Wilmington, Del., this weekend, seeking to use his fourth and final “Quad summit” to cement the alliance between the United States and Indo-Pacific nations and to counter China’s rising influence in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diane Harris
title: Going Solo: How to Plan for Retirement When You’re on Your Own
description: More Americans are entering their later years without people they can automatically turn to for assistance with their health and finances. Here’s how to start.
content: For Sara Zeff Geber, the “aha moment” came a few years ago as she listened to a friend recount all the tasks she was taking on to help her increasingly frail 91-year-old mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Drug Overdose Deaths Are Dropping. The Reasons Are Not Perfectly Clear.
description: The decrease across the country is a major breakthrough in efforts to reverse the effects of fentanyl. Researchers and health officials say there is no easy explanation for the trend.
content: Drug overdose deaths are decreasing sharply across the country, according to recent state and federal data, a dramatic improvement in the nation’s efforts to reverse the consequences of fentanyl’s spread in the illicit drug supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad and Erika Solomon
title: For Families of Those Missing After Israeli Strike in Beirut, an Agonizing Wait
description: With the death toll rising and rescuers still searching for people beneath the rubble, families were keeping a desperate watch over the site of an Israeli strike in Lebanon.
content: After a nightlong vigil, with an untold number of hours of waiting still ahead, Najwa Qubaisi pushed away every relative who tried to coax her from the concrete skeleton of the building that had once been home to her grandson and his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Motel 6 Is Sold to Oyo, an Indian Hotel Company Expanding in the U.S.
description: A roadside chain for more than 50 years, Motel 6 was owned by Blackstone, the private equity giant. Oyo will pay $525 million in an all-cash deal.
content: Motel 6, the budget hotel chain that has lined American highways for decades, will be sold to Oyo, an India-based hotel operator, the companies announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon, Hwaida Saad, Ben Hubbard and Michael Schwirtz
title: Israeli Attacks in Lebanon Mark a Sharp Strategic Shift
description: The events of this week seem to indicate that Israel’s leaders have decided they can no longer live with the threat of Hezbollah on their northern border, analysts say.
content: The death toll from a devastating Israeli airstrike on central Beirut rose to at least 37 on Saturday, with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah confirming that two of its senior commanders were among those killed. Dozens more were wounded in the strikes, which leveled two apartment buildings and plunged Lebanon into further chaos days after pagers and walkie-talkies belonging to Hezbollah members exploded en masse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: A Week of Chaos Pushes Lebanon’s Doctors to the Limit
description: Exploding wireless devices maimed thousands. An Israeli airstrike on Friday flattened two buildings. Many doctors, exhausted, wonder how the country will cope if violence continues.
content: Dr. Dania El-Hallak was already exhausted. After wireless devices exploded across Lebanon, there had been little time to process what she had seen — the hundreds of wounded, many of their faces disfigured beyond recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: How Gina Torres, of ‘Suits’ and ‘9-1-1: Lonestar,’ Spends Her Sundays
description: Ms. Torres starts with a low-key workout, takes a dance break and ends the day with one of her favorite murder-filled TV shows.
content: When Gina Torres recalls the heyday of “Suits,” the legal drama she starred in, she instantly remembers how “insane” the fan base was abroad. But with the resurgence of the show in streaming on Netflix and NBC’s Peacock, suddenly the hype has followed suit in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Earth’s Fall Equinox Ushers In Astronomical Autumn
description: During an equinox, places around the globe experience nearly equal amounts of daytime and nighttime. The second occurrence this year happens on Sunday.
content: This Sunday, the autumnal equinox is upon us, and with it, a shift to shorter days, longer nights and the astronomical start of fall in the Northern Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Kate Mulgrew Walks the Creative and Emotional Plank in ‘The Beacon’
description: Holding tightly to the Dublin accent of her character, the actress talks about starring in Nancy Harris’s feminist thriller at Irish Rep.
content: Sitting in her dressing room on Tuesday at Irish Repertory Theater in Manhattan, talking to me about her latest role, the actress Kate Mulgrew initially sounded like herself: an American from Iowa who happens to share a voice with Kathryn Janeway, the Starfleet captain she played on “Star Trek: Voyager.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,191
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 22, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: JD Vance to Appear With Tucker Carlson, Who Amplified False Holocaust Claims
description: The Republican vice-presidential nominee will share a stage with Mr. Carlson, who was criticized for interviewing a writer who falsely claimed the Holocaust was not an intentional act of genocide.
content: Not long ago, candidates running for national office spent much of the general election distancing themselves from the fringes of their parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: When Is Your HOA Responsible for Repairs in Your Home?
description: State laws govern some of what a homeowners’ association can and can’t do, but the facts of each case are usually what matter most.
content: Q: I live in a townhouse governed by a homeowners’ association in Northern California. Maintenance and repair of the roof falls under the HOA’s responsibilities. Recently, a leak in my roof resulted in water damage. The HOA repaired the leak, but is refusing to address the water damage in my home, suggesting that it’s my responsibility. Shouldn’t the HOA be responsible for repairing that damage as well?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Walzer
title: Israel’s Pager Bombs Have No Place in a Just War
description: Israel is using the tactics of the terrorists it condemns if it indeed was behind the wave of pager and walkie-talkie explosions in Lebanon.
content: The exploding pagers and walkie-talkies targeting members of Hezbollah in Lebanon were certainly an espionage and technological coup. Few people on the spot or reading about them from far away could fail to be amazed. But the explosions on Tuesday and Wednesday were also very likely war crimes — terrorist attacks by a state that has consistently condemned terrorist attacks on its own citizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Billy Edd Wheeler, Songwriter Who Celebrated Rural Life, Dies at 91
description: His plain-spoken songs were recorded by Elvis Presley, Kenny Rogers and many others. The duo of Johnny Cash and June Carter made his “Jackson” a huge country hit.
content: Billy Edd Wheeler, an Appalachian folk singer who wrote vividly about rural life and culture in songs like “Jackson,” a barn-burning duet that was a hit in 1967 for June Carter and Johnny Cash as well as for Nancy Sinatra and Lee Hazlewood, died on Monday at his home in Swannanoa, N.C., east of Asheville. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Greenblatt
title: This Family Is Miserable. You Should Meet Them Anyway.
description: The domestic drama runs high in “A Reason to See You Again,” Jami Attenberg’s latest novel.
content: If the characters in Jami Attenberg’s novels existed on Google Maps, their collective pin would probably drop at a spot called Dysfunction Junction. The smart, deeply flawed people who populate her stories — usually Jewish and located somewhere within the urban flux of New York, Chicago or New Orleans — tend to be driven by art and ambition, along with infidelity, addiction and an almost pathological knack for family schisms. The urge to be likable does not consume them; one could say they are largely immune to the charms of being charming. But the texture of real, messy life lurks in the fallouts, failures and neuroses that spill across the page (and often down their throats; this gang like their alcohol).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: How the Kremlin Finds Ways to Spread Its Messages
description: Social media companies may try to ban RT, the Russian state media broadcaster. But the network has proved in the past to be a wily adversary when confronted with efforts to silence it.
content: Major American social media companies sometimes describe the task of identifying disinformation or other malevolent material pushed online by state actors as an endless game of cat and mouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly Bridson
title: ‘Do You Need a Ride?’
description: Escaping a kidnapper at age 12.
content: I was 12, walking alone on a gray afternoon when a man driving in the same direction slowed down to meet my pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Squishy Truth About Why You’re Seeing Fewer Spotted Lanternflies
description: Your stomping may have helped trim this invasive insect’s population. But experts say other factors probably explain their reduced numbers around New York City.
content: The spotted lanternflies seem to have gone AWOL.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Hopkins
title: Mother Nature Is His Accomplice
description: In Brandon Ndife’s otherworldly domestic sculptures, on view in his New York show, nature shows its ungovernable power.
content: There wasn’t much free ground on which to stand in Brandon Ndife’s Brooklyn studio. Nearly every inch of the space had been swallowed up by a wild profusion of sculptures, which rose from the floor like a dense, unruly forest. The artworks heaved with his facsimiles of botanical life — tree trunks, branches, wheat, vines and vegetables. Twisting and torquing, this biotic matter appeared to be devouring the very things that it had emerged from: quotidian household objects and furniture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Langellier
title: We Are Running Out of Firefighters at a Perilous Time
description: Now would be a good time for Congress to pass a federal spending bill to make a permanent pay increase a reality.
content: Earlier this month, the United States was on the verge of a nightmare scenario. Several Western wildfires were raging at once. In California, San Bernardino County was in a state of emergency; the nearby Bridge Fire had destroyed 54 structures, stretching the state’s resources thin. Smoldering fires were reigniting across Washington and Oregon, and the Davis Fire bore down on ski resorts near Reno, Nev., burning 14 structures. There wasn’t a single elite operations unit available — the kind you call in to manage major wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Clymer and Robert D. McFadden
title: Daniel J. Evans, 98, Washington State Governor Who Went to Senate, Dies
description: A moderate Republican, he championed education, civil rights and environmental causes as a three-term governor and on Capitol Hill. He was eyed as a potential vice president.
content: Daniel J. Evans, a moderate Republican who dominated Washington State politics as a three-term governor and a United States senator and who was repeatedly considered for the vice presidency, died on Friday night at his home in Seattle, about five blocks from where he grew up. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 469
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Sept. 22, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: How the Powerful Outmaneuvered the American Protest Movement
description: It’s time for organizers to invent a new model.
content: The year 2024 started out looking as if it would be a momentous one for political protests. All winter and spring, college campuses were aflame in anger and conflict and as summer approached, the Democratic National Convention threatened to be engulfed by street demonstrations in a potential repeat of the tumultuous 1968 party convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Sally Rooney Thinks Career Growth Is Overrated
description: The star novelist discusses her public persona, the discourse around her work and why reinvention isn’t a goal.
content: The arrival on Sept. 24 of Sally Rooney’s new novel, “Intermezzo,” is one of this fall’s biggest publishing events — not only for the legion of devoted readers hungry for new fiction from the 33-year-old Irish author, but also for the literati ready to devour all the takes and think pieces the book is sure to spawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Heads to North Carolina as Mark Robinson’s Campaign Reels
description: The former president is holding a rally in the battleground state as Mr. Robinson, whom he endorsed for governor, deals with the fallout from a report that he made disturbing online posts.
content: With somewhat awkward timing, former President Donald J. Trump plans to campaign in North Carolina on Saturday as his pick for governor, Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, faces accusations of making disturbing posts on a pornographic website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Christoph Koettl
title: How a U.S. Ally Uses Aid as a Cover in War
description: The United Arab Emirates is expanding a covert campaign to back a winner in Sudan’s civil war. Waving the banner of the Red Crescent, it is also smuggling weapons and deploying drones.
content: The drones soar over the vast deserts along the Sudanese border, guiding weapons convoys that smuggle illicit arms to fighters accused of widespread atrocities and ethnic cleansing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman, Nell Gallogly and Lauren Hirsch
title: Exploding Pagers Deliver a Supply Chain Warning
description: The attacks on Hezbollah in Lebanon are likely to generate greater momentum for moving factory production closer to home.
content: The lethal detonation of hand-held pagers and walkie-talkies used by Hezbollah militants this week in Lebanon demonstrated powerful spycraft, but it also raised questions about a gaping vulnerability in the global supply chain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Reid J. Epstein
title: How One Man’s Vote in Nebraska Could Change the Presidential Election
description: A single Republican state senator appears to be holding back a push by Donald J. Trump to net a potentially pivotal electoral vote even before ballots are cast.
content: In Eastern Nebraska, far from the presidential battleground states, a drama is playing out that could, in a perfectly plausible November scenario, have history-altering repercussions for the nation’s future and the next president — and it may all come down to one man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: After Apple, Jony Ive Is Building an Empire of His Own
description: Five years after leaving Apple, the iPhone designer is forging a new life in San Francisco, one imaginative building at a time.
content: Five years to the week after he walked away from the top job designing the iPhone, Jony Ive leaned over a hulking model of a San Francisco city block. The dozen buildings, with each brick carved to scale in Alder wood, had become a prototype for his future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert Lansdorp, Coach of Tennis Champions, Is Dead at 85
description: His students, including Tracy Austin, Maria Sharapova, Pete Sampras and Lindsay Davenport, developed their ground strokes through his regimen of intense repetition.
content: Robert Lansdorp, a tennis coach whose focus on developing ground strokes through ceaseless repetition helped turn four of his students — Tracy Austin, Pete Sampras, Lindsay Davenport and Maria Sharapova — into No. 1-ranked players in the world, died on Monday in West Carson, Calif. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Norman Reedus, ‘Walking Dead’ Star and Hieronymus Bosch Fan
description: “We wanted to reinvent the show,” the actor said of his spinoff, “The Walking Dead: Daryl Dixon.” Filming in Madrid gave him time to explore the Prado.
content: When Daryl Dixon was introduced in the third episode of “The Walking Dead” in 2010, few viewers could have predicted this half-feral-looking character would end up leading the series. Or that Daryl, played by Norman Reedus, would headline a spinoff set in France.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books for a Real-Life ‘Brilliant Friend’
description: Adventures in Russian literature; a novel of domestic discontent.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Appoints Cabinet as He Seeks to Move France Out of Political Impasse
description: The government still faces two challenges in the coming weeks: the risk of a no-confidence vote and a tight budget deadline.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Saturday appointed a new cabinet that marked a strong shift to the right, in a nation so divided that it took more than two months to form a government whose prospects of long-term stability are far from clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Israeli Strike on Former School Kills 22, Gazan Health Officials Say
description: Gaza’s ministry of health said most of those killed in the strike on the Zeitoun School in Gaza City were women and children.
content: Israel said it struck a school-turned-shelter in Gaza City on Saturday because it believed Hamas militants were using the building as a command center. Palestinian health authorities said the attack killed 22 people, mostly women and children, who had sought shelter at the school, and did not confirm any combatant deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Harris Enters Homestretch With a Far Bigger, Costlier Campaign Than Trump
description: Kamala Harris is collecting more money, spending more money and sitting on more money than Donald J. Trump.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris entered the homestretch of the general election building a campaign that was bigger than former President Donald J. Trump’s in nearly every discernible category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Breakout Performance
description: Jeremy Newton and Tracy Gray’s puzzle offers a great escape.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Padma Lakshmi
title: Padma Lakshmi: As a Cook, Here’s What I See in Kamala Harris
description: The candidate is a proud cook, and cooking is a way to connect.
content: I see what everyone else sees on Kamala Harris’s résumé: a history of public service that qualifies her for the presidency. But I would argue that the qualities she shows as a cook might say even more about her success as a leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Shoulder Season
description: It’s still summer today, but fall arrives tomorrow. Take a minute to pause on the threshold.
content: I received the “They’re back!” text from my friend Greg in Oxford, Miss., on Monday evening. “They” were the Halloween inflatables festooning his neighbor’s lawn, as depicted in an accompanying photo: a jack-o’-lantern with a ghost flailing from each eye, Skeleton Medusa, two spiders the size of Volkswagen Beetles. Greg knows I’m appalled at the ever-earlier arrival of spooky-season décor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
title: Elon Musk’s X Backs Down in Brazil
description: In an abrupt reversal, the social network’s lawyers said it was complying with court orders that it had previously defied. Brazil’s Supreme Court could allow the site to return next week.
content: Elon Musk suddenly appears to be giving up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Easing the Stress Parents Face
description: Parents discuss a guest essay by the surgeon general.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Michael Gold
title: At a Rally in North Carolina, Trump Avoids Topic A: Mark Robinson
description: The former president did not mention Mr. Robinson, the state’s embattled Republican nominee for governor, whom he once called “Martin Luther King on steroids.”
content: Through an awkward quirk of scheduling former President Donald J. Trump found himself headlining a rally in North Carolina on Saturday just two days after the man he endorsed to become the state’s next governor, Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, was accused of making a series of disturbing posts on a pornographic website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris, William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Bianca Pallaro
title: Security Firm Linked to Top Adams Aide Won Millions in N.Y.C. Business
description: The company received a $154 million contract to provide “emergency fire watch services” to the New York City Housing Authority. The firm was once owned by the deputy mayor for public safety.
content: Before Philip B. Banks III was named deputy mayor for public safety for New York City, the security company he once owned rarely did business with the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: A Writer Walks Into a Rave
description: Party-hopping across boroughs with Emily Witt, whose new memoir takes her from literary New York to the city’s underground nightlife scenes.
content: The night out started with New York’s literati and ended with a fog machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Sean Combs and the Limits of the ‘Family Man’ Defense
description: Famous people have long tried to launder their images through their spouses and children.
content: On Monday, Sean Combs was arrested in Manhattan on racketeering and sex trafficking charges. If he’s convicted of the racketeering charge, it could potentially land him a life sentence. His legal team defended him that day with references to his role as a father. “Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs is a music icon, self-made entrepreneur, loving family man and proven philanthropist who has spent the last 30 years building an empire, adoring his children and working to uplift the Black community,” they said in a statement. “He is an imperfect person, but he is not a criminal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Hits 2 More Russian Munition Depots, Aiming to Disrupt War Effort
description: Strikes on weapons arsenals are crucial to weaken Moscow’s overwhelming superiority in battlefield firepower, analysts said.
content: Ukraine said on Saturday that it had struck two large ammunition depots deep inside Russia overnight. It was the second such attack in less than a week as Kyiv seeks to escalate hits on Russian military bases and warehouses to try to disrupt Moscow’s military logistics and slow its troops’ advance on the battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Our Taste for Flesh Has Exhausted the Earth
description: Are we ready for the future of meat?
content: More than almost anything else we put into our mouths, meat matters. What flesh we eat — or forsake — tells the world who we are, what class and caste we belong to, what gods we believe in. Halal or kosher. Pure-veg or paleo. Hormel or farmers’ market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misty White Sidell
title: Naomi Campbell Won’t Stop Her Children From Modeling
description: As long as they get good grades. Plus: a new top editor at i-D magazine and a nascent ‘it’ bag.
content: Naomi Campbell, even after modeling for more than 40 years, still gets nervous before walking a runway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: 10 Unexpected Places Romance Blossomed This Summer
description: Readers share their stories of serendipitous meet-cutes at retreats, museums, cooking classes and grocery stores.
content: There seems to be a lot of misery related to dating these days: unreciprocated energy, commitment issues and swiping fatigue (to name a few).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Rallying in Two Key States, Harris Presses Her Case on Abortion Rights
description: Visiting Wisconsin after giving a speech in Georgia, the vice president signaled she would focus on the life-or-death risks of abortion bans in the final weeks of the race.
content: Rallying supporters in two battleground states, Vice President Kamala Harris signaled on Friday that her closing campaign message would focus on the life-or-death risks that abortion bans pose to American women — and on the argument that former President Donald J. Trump is to blame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamodi Waravita
title: The Incumbent, the Marxist and the Heir: Sri Lanka’s Tight Race for President
description: The country will hold its first presidential election on Saturday since its strongman president fled the country two years ago. Here are the main contenders.
content: Sri Lanka is holding a presidential election on Saturday for the first time since its strongman president fled the country two years ago in the face of protests over an economic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Eric Kim’s ‘Absolutely Amazing’ Pasta Alla Vodka (With Ricotta)
description: I adore this recipe, and so do thousands of readers.
content: Every time I’m tempted to mount my high horse and declare that I don’t need a recipe, I remind myself of the time I tried to make pasta alla vodka without any guidance. (You can probably guess where this is going.) I didn’t cook the sauce long enough, nor did I add enough cream to balance the vodka, and ended up with something like a warm Bloody Mary poured over pasta. It was certainly very boozy, but it wasn’t very delicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Gallogly
title: Women Entrepreneurs Are Hitting a Funding Wall
description: For women starting new businesses, early funding from venture capital firms led by other women is vital. But few are large enough to lead subsequent rounds of financing.
content: When Oriana Papin-Zoghbi was looking for venture capital funding to develop a new type of test for ovarian cancer, she found her pitch did best with women investors. “They were able to resonate with the problem we are trying to solve,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Amy Qin
title: Newsom Signs Bill That Adds Protections for Children on Social Media
description: The California legislation comes amid growing concerns about the impact of cellphones and social media on adolescents’ mental health.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation on Friday aimed at protecting minors from social media addiction amid growing concerns about the impact of technology on adolescents’ mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: When Gunmen Impose a Policy of Rape
description: At the U.N., will President Biden and other world leaders stand up for the victims or for the countries fueling war, rape and hunger?
content: Sudanese refugees who wade across a stream to enter Chad mostly say they leave because of starvation at home. But in tearful whispers, they add that something else is also driving both the starvation and the exodus: mass rape.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 21, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 21, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about the Federal Trade Commission’s findings on the collection and sharing of consumer’s data by some of the biggest online platforms misstated the date and the underlying complaints of the F.T.C.’s settlement with Epic Games. The settlement was reached in late 2022, not in January; and the agency had charged that Epic violated a child privacy law and deceived consumers with unwarranted charges, not just that it violated a child privacy law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattathias Schwartz
title: He Makes Less Than $15,000 and Is Trying to Hold Springfield, Ohio, Together
description: Mayor Rob Rue, whose job is supposed to be part time, finds himself dealing with bomb threats, false rumors and added pressures on city resources.
content: Bomb scares at elementary schools. A police dog checking the bushes outside City Hall. Threats against local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Trump’s Base in North Carolina Still Supports Mark Robinson, but Some Doubt He Can Win
description: At a Trump rally in Wilmington, N.C., many said they would still vote for the embattled Republican nominee for governor.
content: Faithful supporters of former President Donald J. Trump lined up on Saturday afternoon to cheer him on at a rally at the Aero Center in Wilmington, N.C., their red shirts billowing from a beachside breeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: N.Y.P.D.’s Release of Subway Shooting Video Footage Doesn’t Quell Anger
description: After seeing video of officers firing at a knife-wielding man, the cousin of a bystander who was badly hurt in the shooting said the mayor’s explanation did not make sense.
content: Newly released video footage of New York City police officers opening fire on a knife-wielding man at a Brooklyn subway station did not quell anger over their inadvertent shooting of two bystanders, including one who was hit in the head during the burst of gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Human Case of Rare Mosquito-Borne Illness Reported in New York State
description: A person in Ulster County has been hospitalized with Eastern equine encephalitis, health officials said. It is the first confirmed human case of the disease recorded in the state since 2015.
content: A person in New York has been hospitalized with Eastern equine encephalitis, a rare but serious mosquito-borne illness, the state’s Health Department said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How Hard Was Your Workout, Really? There’s a Number for That.
description: Most fitness trackers calculate your “training load.” Here’s what it can and can’t tell you.
content: You just finished a long, hard bike ride. But how hard was it, exactly? That depends on what you measure: How far did you ride, and how fast? How hilly was the route, and what heart rate zones were you in?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Rivalries Are the Heart of College Football. But Many Are Going Away.
description: Upheaval within the Big Ten, Pac-12 and Southeastern Conferences has threatened some cherished rivalries, while rekindling others. In Oregon, the Civil War may soon be over.
content: Travis Beard, wearing a T-shirt commemorating Oregon State’s epic comeback against its rival, the University of Oregon, two years ago that ended with football fans storming the field, was nursing a beer last Saturday on a Reser Stadium concourse, trying to ward off despair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Meet the Birkin Bag of the Book World: Collectible, Covetable and Priced to Match
description: Assouline has made its name publishing tomes that sell for $1,000 or more. But that’s just the beginning of this family-run company’s ambitions.
content: Two decades ago, when Assouline, a leading purveyor of high-end coffee table books and fancy library accouterments, opened its first branded outpost on the seventh floor of Bergdorf Goodman in New York, Prosper Assouline a founder of the company, experienced a kind of epiphany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol, Liev Schreiber, Tanya Pérez, Aaron Esposito, Paul Pontious, Sophia Lanman and Elinor Carucci
title: The Deserter: An Epic Story of Love and War
description: The audio feature, narrated by Liev Schreiber
content: In “The Deserter,” the journalist Sarah A. Topol reports the story of Ivan, a deserter who served as a captain in the Russian Army, fought in Ukraine and then ultimately fled the war and his country with his wife, Anna. (Ivan and Anna are pseudonyms used for their protection.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Another Way of Looking at Jim Crow
description: The purpose of segregation was as much to weaken labor as it was to institutionalize race hierarchy.
content: In the first draft of my Wednesday column, I had a riff toward the end comparing the Trump campaign’s anti-Haitian rhetoric — and the extent to which it may have inspired bomb threats targeting the Haitian community of Springfield, Ohio — to the agitation and demagoguery of segregationist politicians in the Jim Crow South. As I refined the piece, I realized that the comparison, while apt, didn’t quite belong in the column. It detracted from the main thrust of the argument and may have done more to confuse than illuminate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Jennifer Medina, Ruth Igielnik and Maggie Haberman
title: Where Joy Meets Anger: Harris and Trump Battle for Undecided Voters
description: The allegiances of this group of voters — roughly three million people in seven battleground states — are up for grabs, and polling shows they’re pessimistic about the country’s future.
content: Devon Howard is not feeling the joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: As President, Trump Demanded Investigations of Foes. He Often Got Them.
description: He has threatened to target his perceived enemies if elected again. A look at his time in the White House shows how readily he could do so.
content: It was the spring of 2018 and President Donald J. Trump, faced with an accelerating inquiry into his campaign’s ties to Russia, was furious that the Justice Department was reluctant to strike back at those he saw as his enemies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: What We Know (and Don’t Know) About ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Food
description: There’s a growing understanding of the health threats of PFAS chemicals in what we eat and drink.
content: They’re called “forever chemicals” because they basically never break down. They’re linked to ailments including liver disease, certain types of cancers and delayed development in children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Elena Shao
title: Every Falsehood, Exaggeration and Untruth in Trump’s and Harris’s Stump Speeches
description: We fact-checked every sentence of two recent rally speeches and found that Mr. Trump spoke for almost three times as long as Ms. Harris, but told twelve times as many falsehoods or inaccurate statements.
content: We fact-checked every sentence of two recent rally speeches and found that Mr. Trump spoke for almost three times as long as Ms. Harris, but told twelve times as many falsehoods or inaccurate statements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matthew Cullen
title: Here Are Cases of Trump Rivals Who Were Subject to Investigation
description: Those who found themselves under government scrutiny after alienating President Donald J. Trump ranged from the former F.B.I. director to a onetime contestant on “The Apprentice.”
content: Those who found themselves under government scrutiny after alienating President Donald J. Trump ranged from the former F.B.I. director to a onetime contestant on “The Apprentice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, Claire Hogan, Alexandra Ostasiewicz and Laura Salaberry
title: How Trump Tried to Prosecute His Rivals
description: Michael S. Schmidt, a New York Times investigative reporter, explains how Donald Trump used his power as president to intimidate and punish his rivals. Now, in the final weeks of his presidential campaign, Trump has ramped up promises to exact retribution if he returns to the White House.
content: Michael S. Schmidt, a New York Times investigative reporter, explains how Donald Trump used his power as president to intimidate and punish his rivals. Now, in the final weeks of his presidential campaign, Trump has ramped up promises to exact retribution if he returns to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Rebecca Suner, James Surdam, Noah Throop and David Seekamp
title: Who Are the Black Swing Voters?
description: Black voters are not monolithic. Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” asks a political strategist, Prentiss Haney, and Maryland’s governor, Wes Moore, about how Democrats and Republicans can persuade different kinds of Black swing voters.
content: Black voters are not monolithic. Astead W. Herndon, a national reporter for The New York Times and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” asks a political strategist, Prentiss Haney, and Maryland’s governor, Wes Moore, about how Democrats and Republicans can persuade different kinds of Black swing voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li
title: Bodycam Footage Shows Police Shooting in N.Y.C. Subway
description: The New York Police Department released edited body camera footage that shows the moments before and after officers shot a man who they said was wielding a knife at a subway station in Brooklyn.
content: The New York Police Department released edited body camera footage that shows the moments before and after officers shot a man who they said was wielding a knife at a subway station in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Devastating Accounts of Mass Rape I Heard in Darfur
source.name: The New York Times
